issue.title: Performance testing for parallelized versions of Rust/Go/C++ account scraper
issue.body:
Build Rust, Go and parallelized C++ versions of the very basic acctScrape code (here: https://github.com/Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core/tree/master/src/apps/acctScrape).

This very minimal code should do similar processing for each language (parallel) reading the data file and deciding if the given address appears in that file, and if it does, report the 'x' appearance records found there. The format of the binary file is provided below.

This code will not be production level code, so don't spend any time make it pretty or adding options. Once the performance is understood it will be incorporated into the much larger project and mostly re-written.

The performance test will be simple -- we will just run each of the 'go', 'rust' and 'c++' versions against the same folder (with maybe 1000 copies of the data file) using 'time':

  >  time rust_scanner
  >  time go_scanner
  >  time cpp_scanner

There's no need for elaborate options parsing, although the folder name can be a command line option.

The C++ and Go versions are already written and can be found in ./src/other/parallel/cpp in the develop branch.  The Go version needs to be updated to read the binary file. Add the rust versions in the same folder.

Make a PR to the repo when you're ready.

**Here's the file format definition:**

[TrueBlocks Index Digests - File Format.pdf](https://github.com/Great-Hill-Corporation/trueblocks-core/files/4150273/TrueBlocks.Index.Digests.-.File.Format.pdf)

issue.title: acctScrape: Should have a --warp sync mode to download either the blooms or the address index
issue.body: If it's good enough for Parity, it's good enough for us.

issue.title: acctScrape: Copy source code of smart contracts if available
issue.body: The source code of downloaded smart contract should be copied into and made comments of each generated c++ code

issue.title: acctScrape: Seeding an end user with the transaction index
issue.body:
We should offer the end user a couple of options on the first run:

1. Do you want to download the entire 70 GB index from a website (fast, complete for all addresses, helps the community because you can pin it)
2. Do you want to use a remote API that delivers the hashes of only those index files that include your address (fast, complete for you, helps the community because you pin your part).
3. Do you want to generate the index yourself from a Full Node (very slow, partial but will help the community by generating an events-only index)
4. Do you want to generate the full tracing index (slow, helps the community).

There's 3-D table here that would describe these options.

issue.title: blockScrape: User should be able to specify start block for the index
issue.body: And the user should be able to back-fill the data.

issue.title: utillib: toml files should have an upgrade process
issue.body:
When significant changes to a toml file change in the repo, we should have an upgrade process.

One idea is to start with a base toml that always gets overwritten. User customizations could live in another file that supersedes the base config.

issue.title: utillib: There's some commented code in TomlTest2 that shows a hang
etherlib: Size of cache files for logs grew with change from topics being biguints to strings
issue.body:
We could:

1) Change the string to a bytes array (easy)
2) Since logs are tied to a single receipt, and receipts are tied to a single transactions, and since logs are many, many times repeated in a transaction (i.e. airdrops), we could store the topics at the header of the transaction and reference the topics with int16_t in the receipt log. 

Would have to experiment with this, but this issue documents that we grew the size of the data larger than it had to be.

issue.title: install: Notes on installation
issue.body:
There are a few files that must be present for QuickBlocks to work properly. These are copied to $(HOME)/.quickBlocks on installation (at least I think they are, but this may not be consistent). The trouble is that we then refer to the files in the code based on their location depending on the end user having specified a different location for the cache:

Things to do:

1) Find all the files that get copied into $(HOME)/.quickBlocks on running `cmake ../src` if any
2) Find all the files that get copied with `make install` if any
3) Distinguish between files that are needed for proper operation of QBlocks (quickBlocks.toml, names.txt, 0xTokenLib, etc.)
4) Improve the copying/install process so that these files are always present in the $(HOME)/.quickBlocks folder
5) Find all uses of these files in the code and change them so they always look in ~/.quickBlocks ignoring the customized cache location (do this so we can confidently tell the end user they can delete their cache at any time with no loss of function)
6) Decide if copying config files to the local folder is the best way to do these things as opposed to say writing code on initialization of the libraries checks for the existence of the required file and creates is if not found
7) Make this versionable, so if a user later re-installs (or re-builds after a pull), we have a way to rebuild the data in the new format if there is one.

Item (7) argues for item (6).

issue.title: install: various issues
issue.body:
Our installation simply copies the files to `/usr/local/qblocks` which is the right place, but I think it should copy the files to somewhere like `/usr/local/qblocks-version` and then soft link to the above folder to make installing future versions easier.

We should write an installer shell script using either Parity or IFPS as the model.

We may want to look into building a `brew` install for Mac

issue.title: grabABI: Support for new Solidity features
issue.body:
We should find and download the 20,000 test cases from Ethers.js to use these to test our ABI parser. Our parser handles most cases but does not handle two things:

1. byte arrays (and possibly other types of arrays, but I think we handle those correctly)
2. the new syntax for passing definitions of structs through the ABI
    a. https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/develop/abi-spec.html#handling-tuple-types
    b. h t t p s : / / g i t h ub.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/21 (don't link directly, so we don't show in their feed)

The test cases mentioned above cover all those cases. So should our code.

issue.title: grabABI: --generate no longer works and builds in the wrong folder
issue.body: Current, `grabABI` copies files into the parent folder from which it's run. This is bad if it's in a subfolder of a folder you don't want files added to. Instead, it should build files down into a library folder. Currently, it moves into the `parselib` folder and then generates the `classDefinition` files then builds the .cpp files then copies files into the above folder. Do all this from the current folder and build down instead.

issue.title: grabABI: creates statically linked C++ libraries
issue.body:
This is a reminder that 

    grabABI <address> --silent --nodec --generate

creates a statically-linked library of C++ classes and a `CMakeLists.txt` file for the address's functions and events. This includes two functions (`promoteToFunction` and `promoteToEvent`) which take a generic (un-articulated) transaction and returns a `promoted` transaction (or event) which contains populated values for the function. For example, the Solidity function `vote(uint proposalID, bool stance)` would generate a C++ class called `CVote` would have `proposalID` and `stance` as fields.

This capability would make writing code that analyzes smart contracts off-chain much easier. For example, `ether_delta` is a static library could allow you to write custom code on the `ether_delta` contract or use with any token that trades on EtherDelta. This is a very powerful and very useful feature, and it's easy to forget about, thus this reminder.

issue.title: grabABI: may be able to stop building the parselib.cpp file
issue.body:
Search for this line

    "\t\t\t/""/a->articulatedTx.push_back([{PARSEIT}]);\n"

This is in the grabABI.cpp file. The text in the line is commented out because of a change I made as part of making articulation more generic. Part of that work included commenting out all such lines in both tokenlib.cpp and walletlib.cpp since I no longer needed to articulate things in this way.

**Issue:** can we totally remove walletlib and tokenlib and have both of them fully driven by a JSON abi file? I think the articulation in getTrans already works that way (in other words, it works without the tokenlib and walletlib lbraries). If that's right (it is), does it mean that tokenlib and walletlib are no longer needed (I think it does).

**One caveat:** The only place where tokenlib and walletlib may be useful is for building actual classes out of the functions of the ABI which might be useful for IoT or customized monitors as per the way I used to do things prior to 0.6.0

issue.title: grabABI: Code generation for fallback and constructor not correct
issue.body:
`grabABI` doesn't handle the constructor or the fallback functions correctly when generating monitor code. Monitoring code is used to articulate the data.

Search for this code:

```
if (!func.name.empty())
    functions[functions.getCount()] = func;
```

If one removes this code, a new function name will appear in some of the `grabABI` tests, but they are not correct.

Also--for the `DAO` and `ENS` contracts, as an example, we force the correct behavior in the `promoteTransaction` function.

I'm not sure how to handle this since each smart contract's constructors and fallbacks are different.

**Notes:**
The ABI file does not include the name of the smart contract (not the interface for its constructor). This makes it impossible to parse the input to the constructor. It also makes it necessary to 'name' the contract externally. If the ABI included the name of the smart contract, automated auditing code could use that name to better process the activity on the contract. This may be an idea for an Ethereum EIP. Automated auditing tools want to be able to read the ABI and fully articulate all interactions with that contract.

The downsides of this approach would be that the names of contracts are not unique, but that can be handled by the end-user, it should not be decided by the person who wrote the code that generated the ABI. The system should allow the user to make a decision about how to use it.
